Title: Algae farming
Limitations for Symphony: The chl-a index were mapped under curtain period of time using cut off threshold, this could underestimate or overestimated the actual eurotripication within the region
Method Summary: Using data provided by Be Geospatial AB, algae farming locations were manually selected. To extract Chl-a concentration values, which serve as an indicator for eutrophication, 10-km buffer zones were applied around the algae farming sites. These values were obtained from GCOM, and subsequently linearly normalized within a 1-100 scale, and mapped onto a reference grid. Maximum value representation: chl-a index in mg/m3/year. GeoTIFF download: https://github.com/WIOSymphony/wiosym/raw/main/products/v2.1/output_geotiffs/eco/algae_farming.tif. Citation: Zerne P (2023). Algae farming - ecosystem component from the WIO Symphony tool. URL: https://github.com/WIOSymphony/.
Data Processing: Zerne P, 2023. Arcpy, javascript, script: aqualculture.py, mariculture_aquaculture_v2.py
Data Sources: Beltran J. Coastal development in the West Indian Ocean [dataset]. 2022 [accessed 2022 Jun 27]. BE Geospatial. Available from: contact jose.beltran@begeospatial.com\
column11: Murakami H. ATBD of GCOM-C chlorophyll-a concentration algorithm (Version 1) [dataset]. 2018 [accessed 2021 Dec 22]. Available from: https://developers.google.com/earth-engine/datasets/catalog/JAXA_GCOM-C_L3_OCEAN_CHLA_V1

Title: Mariculture
Limitations for Symphony: The chl-a index were mapped under curtain period of time using cut off threshold, this could underestimate or overestimated the actual eurotripication within the region
Method Summary: Using data provided by Be Geospatial AB, specific points within distinct coastal features associated with shrimp farming locations and offshore fish farming areas were manually selected. To extract Chl-a concentration values, which serve as an indicator for eutrophication, 10-km buffer zones were applied around the mariculture sites. These values were obtained from GCOM, and subsequently linearly normalized within a 1-100 scale, and mapped onto a reference grid. Maximum value representation: chl-a index in mg/m3/year. GeoTIFF download: https://github.com/WIOSymphony/wiosym/raw/main/products/v2.1/output_geotiffs/eco/mariculture.tif. Citation: Zerne P (2023). Mariculture - ecosystem component from the WIO Symphony tool. URL: https://github.com/WIOSymphony/.
Data Processing: Zerne P, 2023. Arcpy, javascript, script: aqualculture.py, mariculture_aquaculture_v2.py

Title: Ocean acidification
Limitations for Symphony: Data are confident to the 90th percentile (data with uncertainty factors above 10% were excluded).
Method Summary: This ocean monitoring indicator (OMI) consists of annual mean rates of changes in surface ocean pH (yr-1) computed at 1°×1° resolution from 1985 until the last year. This indicator is derived from monthly pH time series distributed with the Copernicus Marine product MULTIOBS_GLO_BIO_CARBON_SURFACE_REP_015_008 (Chau et al., 2022a). Maximum value representation: per year. GeoTIFF download: https://github.com/WIOSymphony/wiosym/raw/main/products/v2.1/output_geotiffs/eco/ocean_acidification.tif. Citation: Queste BY (2023). Ocean acidification - ecosystem component from the WIO Symphony tool. URL: https://github.com/WIOSymphony/.

Limitations for Symphony: The altimeter data is not corrected for the effect of the Glacial Isostatic Adjustment nor the TOPEX-A instrumental drift during the period 1993-1998. Low resolution up-scaled to grid

Title: Storm surges
Limitations for Symphony: Product developed on ensemble CMIP6 data at lower resolution, then up-scaled to match the WIOSYM grid.
Method Summary: Map of 50-year return surge levels, in meters, computed from time series data available in the Climate Data Store, named Global sea level change time series from 1950 to 2050, derived from reanalysis and high-resolution CMIP6 climate projections. Title: Dredging
Limitations for Symphony: The TSM index were mapped under curtain period of time using cut off threshold, this could underestimate or overestimated the actual turbidity within the region
Method Summary: This layer was produced by using manually collected data provided by Be Geospatial AB. The collected points were separated within different coastal features. 5-km buffer zones were used for masking around the dredging sites and beach mining sites to extract Total Suspended Matter (TSM) values derived from MODIS. Then the values were linearly normalized within a 1-100 scale, and mapped onto the reference grid. Maximum value representation: TSM index mg/m3/year. GeoTIFF download: https://github.com/WIOSymphony/wiosym/raw/main/products/v2.1/output_geotiffs/eco/dredging.tif. Citation: Zerne P (2023). Dredging - ecosystem component from the WIO Symphony tool. URL: https://github.com/WIOSymphony/.
Data Sources: Beltran J. Coastal development in the West Indian Ocean [dataset]. 2022 [accessed 2022 Jun 27]. BE Geospatial. Available from: contact jose.beltran@begeospatial.com\

Limitations for Symphony: The manually corrected data using the sattelite images within the curtain period of time, it could miss out some exist activities within this region and contain data gaps.

Title: Industrial pollution
Limitations for Symphony: The TSM index were mapped under curtain period of time using cut off threshold, this could underestimate or  overestimated the actual turbidity within the region, the buffer zones also can underestimate the actual pollution that may occur outside the buffer zone.
Method Summary: A turbidity proxy based on yearly average total suspended matter (TSM), derived from MODIS satellite data, was used together with Chlorophyll-a concentrations derived from the Global Change Observation Mission (GCOM-C) for 01/01/2020 to 31/12/2020. 50- km buffer zones were applied to power plant locations based on WRI (Primary fuel types: Nuclear, Coal, Biomass, Oil, Gas, Geothermal and Waste). These buffered areas were used as a reference mask to extract the turbidity index to map water pollution near the power plant locations. Maximum value representation: generation capacity tMw/year. GeoTIFF download: https://github.com/WIOSymphony/wiosym/raw/main/products/v2.1/output_geotiffs/eco/industrial_pollution.tif. Citation: Zerne P (2022). Industrial pollution - ecosystem component from the WIO Symphony tool. URL: https://github.com/WIOSymphony/.
Data Processing: Zerne P, 2022. Arcpy, script: water_movement_change.py, water_movement_change2.py
Data Sources: Jarvis A, Reuter H.I, Nelson A, Guevara E. Hole-filled seamless SRTM data V4, International Centre for Tropical Agriculture (CIAT) [dataset]. 2008 [accessed 2020 Apr 2]. NASA Earth Observations. Available from: http://srtm.csi.cgiar.org\

Title: Light pollution
Limitations for Symphony: Light data from VIIRS sattelite is spatially accurate but it is difficult to judge the intensity and frequency of light pollution on the ground
Method Summary: The annual time series of global VIIRS nighttime lights were used, derived from monthly averages from 2012 to 2019 provided by NASA. The focal moving window weight matrix was applied, and Gaussian filters with a 5000 meter radius were used. Maximum value representation: Presence/absence. GeoTIFF download: https://github.com/WIOSymphony/wiosym/raw/main/products/v2.1/output_geotiffs/eco/light_pollution.tif. Citation: Kågesten G (2022). Light pollution - ecosystem component from the WIO Symphony tool. URL: https://github.com/WIOSymphony/.
Data Sources: Elvidge C D, Zhizhin M, Ghosh T, Hsu F-C. Annual time series of global VIIRS nighttime lights derived from monthly averages: 2012 to 2019 [dataset]. 2021 [accessed 2021 Jun 11]. Remote Sensing (In press). Available from: https://eogdata.mines.edu/products/vnl/

Title: Nutrient input
Limitations for Symphony: The chl-a index were mapped under curtain period of time using cut off threshold, this could underestimate or overestimated the actual eurotripication within the region
Method Summary: A weighted sum model was used for predicting nutrient pollutions, and the results were linearly normalized to a 1-100 scale. The predictors included in the model are surface current velocity, hydrological flow accumulation, run-off volume (curve number modelling on land covers), chlorophyll-a concentrations, and dissolved inorganic nutrients (phosphate and nitrate from the World Ocean Atlas 2018, and land-based nutrients on fertilizer use (N,P,K) in soils from iSDA). Maximum value representation: chla index in mg/m3 (2017-2022). GeoTIFF download: https://github.com/WIOSymphony/wiosym/raw/main/products/v2.1/output_geotiffs/eco/nutrient_input.tif. Citation: Zerne P (2023). Nutrient input - ecosystem component from the WIO Symphony tool. URL: https://github.com/WIOSymphony/.
Data Processing: Zerne P, 2023. Arcpy, Javascript, script: nutrient_input_model.py, nutrient_inputv2_aug2022.py
Data Sources: Jarvis A, Reuter H.I, Nelson A, Guevara E. Hole-filled seamless SRTM data V4, International Centre for Tropical Agriculture (CIAT) [dataset]. 2008 [accessed 2020 Apr 2]. NASA Earth Observations. Available from: http://srtm.csi.cgiar.org\
column10: Murakami H. ATBD of GCOM-C chlorophyll-a concentration algorithm (Version 1) [dataset]. 2018 [accessed 2021 Dec 22]. Available from: https://developers.google.com/earth-engine/datasets/catalog/JAXA_GCOM-C_L3_OCEAN_CHLA_V1

Title: Artisanal fishing
Limitations for Symphony: The source data for this layer was obtained by manually pin-pointing boats in Google Earth. This was performed by several individuals. A protocol was established for identifying artisinal fishing boats. However, there is a risk that boats were incorrectly identified as artisinal fishing boats, or were missed.
Method Summary: A model that calculates the least cost paths from boat locations to all other ocean pixels was used. The model estimates artisanal fishing pressure based on a kernel density model, which assumes that the probability of a moored boat fishing at a given location declines with distance from the moored boat. Artisanal fishing boat locations and densities were estimates using Google Earth satellite imagery, marking out boats likely to be used for artisanal fishing. Maximum value representation: NA. GeoTIFF download: https://github.com/WIOSymphony/wiosym/raw/main/products/v2.1/output_geotiffs/eco/artisanal_fishing.tif. Citation: Sacre E (2022). Artisanal fishing - ecosystem component from the WIO Symphony tool. URL: https://github.com/WIOSymphony/.
Data Sources: The Nature Concervancy, Mapping Ocean Wealth project. MOW_CR_Fisheries [dataset]. [accessed 2021 Sep 28]. Available from: contact kathryn.longley-wood@tnc.org\

Title: Crustacean pots
Limitations for Symphony: The Global Fishing Watch data is based on advanced algorithms to estimate fishing effort. However, there is a risk that vessels are incorrectly identified as fishing in the algorithm. Further, these data may not identify unregistered fishing boats.
Method Summary: Mean yearly fishing hours in each grid cell were calculated from the years 2012-2020, based on Global Fishing Watch data, for vessels registered as using pots and traps. Kernel density modelling was then performed with a 50-km radius to remove noise. Maximum value representation: 7 fishing hours per year. GeoTIFF download: https://github.com/WIOSymphony/wiosym/raw/main/products/v2.1/output_geotiffs/eco/crustacean_pots.tif. Citation: Sacre E (2022). Crustacean pots - ecosystem component from the WIO Symphony tool. URL: https://github.com/WIOSymphony/.
Data Sources: Kroodsma D A, Mayorga J, Hochberg T, Miller N A, Boerder K, Ferretti F, Wilson A, Bergman B, White T D, Block B A, Woods P, Sullivan B, Costello C, Worm B. Tracking the global footprint of fisheries, Daily Fishing Effort and Vessel Presence at 100th Degree Resolution by Flag State and Gear Type, version 2.0, 2012-2020 [datset]. 2020 [accessed 2021 May 27]. Science 361.6378 (2018). Available from: https://globalfishingwatch.org/data-download/datasets/public-fishing-effort

Title: Other fishing
Limitations for Symphony: The relationship between boat detections from night lights and fishing activity has been shown in numerous publications, still the link between the fishing pressure and the lights is uncertain. Some boat detections from other activities such as around ports and boat activities around oil platforms are still in the data, but spatial patterns of obvious unreported fishing activities can also be seen.
Method Summary: The other fishing layer is based on vessel detections 2017-2020 by Elvidge C et al using NASA VIIRS nightlight data which was then interpolated using focal statistics to provide intensity of vessels observed in each area. The intensity layer was normalised 0-100 and adjusted to normalised data from all known fishing activities, as well as port and fixed lights from oil platforms. The residual which were only captured by the night light vessel detection is what makes up the “Other fishing” layer, assuming it is mainly unreported fishing which is the light emitting night activity taking place there.

Bandnumber: Maximum value representation: relative intensity. GeoTIFF download: https://github.com/WIOSymphony/wiosym/raw/main/products/v2.1/output_geotiffs/eco/other_fishing.tif. Title: Pelagic seine
Limitations for Symphony: The Global Fishing Watch data is based on advanced algorithms to estimate fishing effort. However, there is a risk that vessels are incorrectly identified as fishing in the algorithm. Further, these data may not identify unregistered fishing boats.
Method Summary: Mean yearly fishing hours in each grid cell were calculated from the years 2012-2020, based on Global Fishing Watch data, for vessels registered as using tuna purse seines. Kernel density modelling was then performed with a 200-km radius to remove noise. Maximum value representation: 97 fishing hours per year. GeoTIFF download: https://github.com/WIOSymphony/wiosym/raw/main/products/v2.1/output_geotiffs/eco/pelagic_seine.tif. Citation: Sacre E (2022). Pelagic seine - ecosystem component from the WIO Symphony tool. URL: https://github.com/WIOSymphony/.

Title: Weighted longline
Limitations for Symphony: The Global Fishing Watch data is based on advanced algorithms to estimate fishing effort. However, there is a risk that vessels are incorrectly identified as fishing in the algorithm. Further, these data may not identify unregistered fishing boats.
Method Summary: Mean yearly fishing hours in each grid cell were calculated from the years 2012-2020, based on Global Fishing Watch data, for vessels registered as using set longlines. Kernel density modelling was then performed with a 50-km radius to remove noise. Maximum value representation: 17 fishing hours per year. GeoTIFF download: https://github.com/WIOSymphony/wiosym/raw/main/products/v2.1/output_geotiffs/eco/weighted_longline.tif. Citation: Sacre E (2022). Weighted longline - ecosystem component from the WIO Symphony tool. URL: https://github.com/WIOSymphony/.
Data Sources: Kroodsma D A, Mayorga J, Hochberg T, Miller N A, Boerder K, Ferretti F, Wilson A, Bergman B, White T D, Block B A, Woods P, Sullivan B, Costello C, Worm B. Tracking the global footprint of fisheries, Daily Fishing Effort and Vessel Presence at 100th Degree Resolution by Flag State and Gear Type, version 2.0, 2012-2020 [datset]. 2020 [accessed 2021 May 27]. Science 361.6378 (2018). Available from: https://globalfishingwatch.org/data-download/datasets/public-fishing-effort

Title: Ghost fishing
Limitations for Symphony: This layer is based on proximity to fishing activites and does not take into account ocean currents, which are likely to play a role in the distribution of ghost fishing gear.
Method Summary: Gear loss risks were simulated by multiplying the fishing efforts per gear type with published gear loss factors, with subsequent distribution in space using a kernels function. The fishing gear loss factors are based on “proportion of gear lost” from Tables 1 to 3 in Richardson et al. 2019 (“Estimates of fishing gear loss rates at a global scale: A literature review and meta‐analysis”, Fish and Fisheries 20, 1218-1231). For pole and lines, the Richardson et al. 2019 estimate of 0.65 was stated to be an overestimate (Pham et al., 2021, “Abandoned, Lost or Otherwise Discarded Fishing Gear (ALDFG) in Tuna Pole-and-Line Fisheries”). We therefore decided to instead use the longline loss factor also for poles and lines. For dredging, we applied the loss factors of bottom trawling. For nets and lines, we assumed drifting distances of up to 1000 km, see Stelfox et al. 2020 for trajectory simulations (“Minimum drift times infer trajectories of ghost nets found in the Maldives”, Marine Pollution Bulletin 154, 111037). For pots and traps, we assumed that they sink faster than nets and lines, and set drifting distances of up to 300 km (no reference). Maximum value representation: 15% gear loss rate. GeoTIFF download: https://github.com/WIOSymphony/wiosym/raw/main/products/v2.1/output_geotiffs/eco/ghost_fishing.tif. Citation: Sacre E (2022). Ghost fishing - ecosystem component from the WIO Symphony tool. URL: https://github.com/WIOSymphony/.
Data Sources: Kroodsma D A, Mayorga J, Hochberg T, Miller N A, Boerder K, Ferretti F, Wilson A, Bergman B, White T D, Block B A, Woods P, Sullivan B, Costello C, Worm B. Tracking the global footprint of fisheries, Daily Fishing Effort and Vessel Presence at 100th Degree Resolution by Flag State and Gear Type, version 2.0, 2012-2020 [datset]. 2020 [accessed 2021 May 27]. Science 361.6378 (2018). Available from: https://globalfishingwatch.org/data-download/datasets/public-fishing-effort

Title: Plastic litter
Limitations for Symphony: The plastic layer is limited by the resolution and accuracy of a global model. To better represent the coastal area and trace the local sources of plastic pollution, additional data such as high resolution, satellite imagery, land-cover data, census data, and other relevant data sources would be needed.
Method Summary: A new global model of plastic pollution in the oceans and coastline, available as 60-km hexagon grids, was adjusted to the WIO Symphony 1-km grid. Data was available for a range of particle sizes, as particle mass or concentration and with predictions from years 2015, 2020 and 2025. For the WIO Symphony model, total concentration of particles larger than 5 mm from the 2020 prediction was used. The data was split up in two ways, the shore prediction, and the pelagic data (divided into 0-5 m (surface), 5-50 m, 50-500 m and 500 m-inf depth layers). The interpolation for each individual layer was made using the centre points of the hexagon grids, applying Inverse Distance Weighting at 10-km spacing, then converting to a 1-km grid using bilinear interpolation. Shoreline plastic: The interpolated plastic shore data model was multiplied with the WIO Symphony shore layer which contains the proportion of shoreline within each pixel, hence assuming more complex shorelines result in a higher pressure from plastic pollution within a 1-km pixel. In addition, a 2-km Gaussian filter was run and combined with this data, assuming plastic has a local spread into the nearby environment. Finally, the data was normalized to 0-100 using the maximum value in the WIO region (99% quantile to exclude outliers). Pelagic plastic: The interpolated concentrations of plastic particles for each depth layer where combined using the maximum value in each 1-km grid cell. The data were then normalized to 0-100 using the global maximum value (99% quantile to exclude outliers). Combined product: The two normalized layers were combined into one using the maximum value in each cell. As a nod to the theory behind the layer created for v01 of WIO Symphony (using extrapolation from the main river sources), areas highlighted as polluted in v01 were included if 10% of the max value was greater than v02 (e.g., max(plastic_v01 * 0.1, plastic v02)). This step mainly added plastic pollution in areas close to large rivers with high plastic concentrations, not always captured in the coarser global 60-km hexagon models. Maximum value representation: High plastic concentrations relative to global data - grams/m3 in the ocean, grams/m on beaches. GeoTIFF download: https://github.com/WIOSymphony/wiosym/raw/main/products/v2.1/output_geotiffs/eco/plastic_litter.tif. Citation: Kågesten G, Zerne P, Hammar L, Kaandorp M (2023). Plastic litter - ecosystem component from the WIO Symphony tool. URL: https://github.com/WIOSymphony/.
Data Processing: Kågesten G, Zerne P, Hammar L, Kaandorp M, 2023. R ver. 4.1.1., script: pres_pol_plastic_reg_s01_v02.0.Rmd
Data Sources: Kaandorp MLA, Lobelle D, Kehl C, Dijkstra HA, van Sebille E. The global marine plastic mass budget is dominated by large long-lived objects [dataset]. 2023 [accessed 2023 March 10]. In press, Supplementary Material. Available from: https://github.com/OceanParcels/GlobalMassBudget/tree/main/00_resulting_maps\

Title: Oil gas industry
Limitations for Symphony: This model does not take into account ocean currents that would likely have a large influence on the dispersal of hydrocarbons.
Method Summary: A kernel density model of oil and gas platforms and pipelines was used, based on data from MapStand. Platforms were assumed to discharge 45 kgs of hydrocarbons per year in their immediate proximity, based on estimates by the National Research Council (US) Committee on Oil in the Sea (2003, https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/25057607/). Pipelines were assumed to discharge 46 kgs of hydrocarbons per year in their immediate proximity, based on the same source. Thus, the output layer is scaled from 0-100, with 100 representing 91 kg of hydrocarbon discharge per year, and a value of 1 representing 0.91 kg of discharge per year, scaling linearly. Maximum value representation: 91 kg of hydrocarbon discharge per year. GeoTIFF download: https://github.com/WIOSymphony/wiosym/raw/main/products/v2.1/output_geotiffs/eco/oil_gas_industry.tif. Citation: Sacre E (2022). Oil gas industry - ecosystem component from the WIO Symphony tool. URL: https://github.com/WIOSymphony/.
Data Sources: MapStand Limited. MapStand Global Energy Database 2022 [dataset]. 2022 [accessed 2021 Oct 25]. Available from: https://mapstand.com, contact support@mapstand.com

Title: Submarine cables
Limitations for Symphony: The beffer zone can gives the bias to capture effect within this activity.

Symphony Category: Data on telecommunication submarine cables were used, from Greg's Cable Map (Greg Mahlknecht) and Telegeography, and merged together. Then, a focal statistics spatial analysis was performed using a wedge-shaped neighborhood by summation of 20 pixels cell radius within 0-360 degree looking angles. Finally, a linear normalization within a 0-100 scale was performed. Maximum value representation: presence/absence. GeoTIFF download: https://github.com/WIOSymphony/wiosym/raw/main/products/v2.1/output_geotiffs/eco/submarine_cables.tif. Citation: Zerne P (2022). Submarine cables - ecosystem component from the WIO Symphony tool. URL: https://github.com/WIOSymphony/.

Title: Air pollution
Limitations for Symphony: The sulfer dioxide and nitrogen dioxide indexed were used to capture air pollution were based on curtain time period, it also used the cut off threshould that may cause the bias on identifying the actual pollution.
Method Summary: Satellite products of a Sentinel-5P from the European Space Agency were used. The records of a TROPOMI instrument multispectral sensor for measuring atmospheric concentrations of carbon monoxide, nitrogen oxide, and sulphur dioxide from 01/01/2021 - 31/12/2021 were used to calculate yearly average concentrations. The results of these three air pollution indicators were combined, and focal statistics were performed using a summation of 100 pixels cell circle neighborhood. Finally, a log-10 transformation was applied together with a linear normalization to a 1-100 scale. Maximum value representation: mol/m3. GeoTIFF download: https://github.com/WIOSymphony/wiosym/raw/main/products/v2.1/output_geotiffs/eco/air_pollution.tif. Citation: Zerne P (2022). Air pollution - ecosystem component from the WIO Symphony tool. URL: https://github.com/WIOSymphony/.
Data Processing: Zerne P, 2022. Arcpy, Javascript, script: air_pol_v1.py\
Data Sources: air_pol_v2.py

Title: Inorganic toxins
Limitations for Symphony: The collected data on this layers also missing the recorded on the chemical data on soem locations, the proxy hydrology model can cause the bias on identifying the actual pollution in some of the areas.
Method Summary: The contamination data from The Toxic Sites Identification Program (TSIP) was used. The inorganic toxin data were extracted and combined with a hydrological flow accumulation to identify the inorganic pollution area within a reference grid. Title: Boating
Limitations for Symphony: Vessel activities from smaller boats, and other water crafts which are not using AIS systems are not included in this dataset
Method Summary: AIS data 2020-2022 supplied by HUB Ocean where used to map time (hours/week) spent by passenger boats within each 1km pixel. Maximum value representation: Boat intensity 24h/week or more. GeoTIFF download: https://github.com/WIOSymphony/wiosym/raw/main/products/v2.1/output_geotiffs/eco/boating.tif. Title: Coastal tourism
Limitations for Symphony: Hotels/accomodation may not necessarily perfectly represent pressures from marine tourism, as hotel density may be higher in certain areas for other reasons, such as terrestrial tourism.
Method Summary: A kernel density model of all hotels and lodges registered in Google Earth was used, applying a kernel density radius of 10 km. Maximum value representation: 57 hotels per square kilometre. GeoTIFF download: https://github.com/WIOSymphony/wiosym/raw/main/products/v2.1/output_geotiffs/eco/coastal_tourism.tif. Title: Diving
Limitations for Symphony: This layer assumes that the number of dive centres is proportional to diving activities and does not take into account the size or popularity of the diving centres.
Method Summary: A kernel density model of all dive centers registered within OpenStreetMaps was used, applying a kernel density radius of 10 km. Maximum value representation: 5 dive centres per square kilometre. GeoTIFF download: https://github.com/WIOSymphony/wiosym/raw/main/products/v2.1/output_geotiffs/eco/diving.tif. Citation: Sacre E (2022). Diving - ecosystem component from the WIO Symphony tool. URL: https://github.com/WIOSymphony/.

Title: Ship pollution
Limitations for Symphony: Calculations are not taking ship speed into account. The estimation of ship pollution based on vesseltypes and hours spent are uncertain as it does not have more detailed information of the cargo and environmental precautions of each ship.
Method Summary: Ship pollution was estimated using global AIS data 2020-2022 provided by HUB Ocean. The data was divided into ship classes and summarized by ship time / year spent in each 1km gridcell. Maximum value representation: pollution exposure h/year. GeoTIFF download: https://github.com/WIOSymphony/wiosym/raw/main/products/v2.1/output_geotiffs/eco/ship_pollution.tif. Citation: Kågesten G, Zerne P (2022). Title: Ship strike
Limitations for Symphony: Calculations are not taking ship speed into account.
Method Summary: Risk of ship strikes was estimated using global AIS data 2020-2022 provided by HUB Ocean. The data was divided into ship classes and summarized by ship time / year spent in each 1km gridcell. Ship time at anchor points was removed assuming vesselspeed at these locations were to low to risk collitions. Maximum value representation: shipstrike h/year. GeoTIFF download: https://github.com/WIOSymphony/wiosym/raw/main/products/v2.1/output_geotiffs/eco/ship_strike.tif. Citation: Kågesten G (2022). Ship strike - ecosystem component from the WIO Symphony tool. URL: https://github.com/WIOSymphony/.

Title: Underwater noise
Limitations for Symphony: The spreading of sound in the ocean and the interaction with marine life is very complex and a more detailed map would need a detailed oceanographic model to go along with it, as well as sound data for every vessel, and more. The model makes some simple assumptions to get the spreading of sound and the intensity of its occurrence on the map for planners to see where risk of impact is higher or lower. More detailed studies are needed to understand its impact on marine life.
Method Summary: Ship noise and exposure time were estimated from global AIS data 2020-2022 provided by HUB Ocean. The spreading of sound was calculated using the mean frequency and noise level for each ship class combined with a custom focal statistics filter which takes spreading of sound at different sound frequencies in account. Maximum value representation: Watt h/year (high impact 140db). GeoTIFF download: https://github.com/WIOSymphony/wiosym/raw/main/products/v2.1/output_geotiffs/eco/underwater_noise.tif. Citation: Kågesten G (2022). Underwater noise - ecosystem component from the WIO Symphony tool. URL: https://github.com/WIOSymphony/.
Data Processing: Kågesten G, 2022. R ver. 4.1.1, script: act_ship_reg_s01_v01.2.Rmd
Data Sources: HUB Ocean - Ocean Data Platform, Global Fishing Watch, IHS Markit, Spire AIS. HUB Ocean Vessel Density Maps [dataset]. 2022 [accessed 2022 Sep 24]. Available from: www.hubocean.earth, contact Kristian Authen <Kristian.Authen@oceandata.earth>

Title: Seismic surveys
Limitations for Symphony: This layer assumes that the pressure of a a seismic survey correlates with its recency, although there may be other factors influencing the intensity of the pressures, such as depth or the shape of the seafloor.

Symphony Category: Using seismic survey data from MapStand, seismic survey lines were converted to raster and given a linear weighting based on the frequency of the seismic survey. The output layer is scaled from 0-100. The dataset contains seismic surveys from the years 1969 to 2019. Thus, a value of 100 represents seismic surveys performed in 2019, a value of 50 represents seismic surveys performed in 1994, and a value of 1 represents seismic surveys performed in 1969. A value of zero indicates no record of seismic surveys occurring in that grid cell within the dataset. Maximum value representation: Close proximity (less than 1 km) from underwater seismic surveys performed in the last 5 years. GeoTIFF download: https://github.com/WIOSymphony/wiosym/raw/main/products/v2.1/output_geotiffs/eco/seismic_surveys.tif. Citation: Sacre E (NA). Seismic surveys - ecosystem component from the WIO Symphony tool. URL: https://github.com/WIOSymphony/.

Limitations for Symphony: MapStand Limited. MapStand Global Energy Database 2022, Acoustic Surveys [dataset]. 2022 [accessed 2021 Oct 25]. Available from: https://mapstand.com, contact support@mapstand.com
